Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1351613
Snyder

The primary transformative scientific impact of this CAREER program will be the development of novel and scalable strategies for reducing carbon molecular sieve (CMS) film thickness to unprecedented nanometer-scale levels for orders of magnitude improvement in flux and industrially relevant selectivities. The intellectual merit will be further defined by the fundamental elucidation of critical synthesis-structure-function relations governing how nanoscale confinement, through its control of CMS microstructure, can serve as a powerful handle for tuning CMS texture and thus selectivity. Success of this program will create a transformative shift in the paradigm for CMS membrane synthesis, establish new insights into tunable synergies between material structure and function, and, thereby, set the stage for CMS membranes, and even related inorganic membranes, to realize the quantum leap in performance that is required to meet and exceed demands for industrial viability.

Underlying this CAREER program is the desire to establish synergies between materials synthesis and molecular-level understanding in order to realize rational materials design. The resulting hierarchically structured materials and mechanistic insight into membrane transport should lead to new synthesis paradigms in membrane technologies and applications as far-reaching as sensing, catalysis, and storage. A keystone of the broader impact will be the development of a novel three-tiered (i.e., illustration-guided demonstration-assessment) inquiry-based learning module titled "Molecular Traffic Control" that will apply HEXBUG NanoÂ®s for a macroscopic illustration of molecular diffusion and interactions. A multi-level implementation strategy will leverage this module for increasingly broad dissemination starting with a local middle school science class and Saturday science/math academy (STAR Academy) composed of a culturally diverse, socioeconomically challenged group of students. Subsequent extension to all middle school science classes, district science classes, and eventual implementation at the regional science fair for students, teachers, and parents is planned. The CAREER program will also impact graduate students involved directly and indirectly in the proposed work by providing them with breadth and depth of knowledge in fields of membranes/transport phenomena, materials synthesis, and materials characterization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project established a hierarchical templating approach capable of tailoring the morphology, mesoporosity, microstructure, and thus function of porous carbon replicas for applications spanning adsorption- and membrane-based molecular separations to high-performance supercapacitors and solar cells. The primary outcome of the project that embodies its intellectual merit is the identification and mechanistic understanding of how surface chemistry of assembled silica nanoparticle templates can be leveraged as a previously unexploited handle for engineering the microstructure of various classes of replica carbons.  Specifically, the project has demonstrated how interfacial templating not only enhances the surface area and mesopore volume of replica carbons, but offers unique simultaneous control of carbon microstructure without the need for excessively high temperatures or catalysts. Additional key outcomes of the project include the identification of sequential templating and template-replica co-assembly strategies leading to 1) new classes of hierarchically structured carbons with interdigitated pore topologies and attractive supercapacitor properties and 2) self-supported asymmetric membranes comprised of ultrathin (ca. 10 nm) carbon molecular sieve films that are transferable among substrates and show promise for high-flux small molecule separations. A final outcome of the project involves the identification of an interface-mediated route to hierarchically structured carbons comprised of ultrathin (ca. 5-10 nm) microporous petal-like features and the determination of structure-function relations leading to their design as competitive CO2 sorbents.

Contributing to its broader impact, the project has extended the identified interfacial phenomenon across the materials palette to realize analogous template-mediated stabilization and control of polymorphism in hierarchically porous metal oxides (e.g, TiO2, ZrO2). Collectively, the scientific outcomes of the project offer new strategies for the design and engineering of materials with relevance to the broader energy and environmental sectors.

Key sustainable educational outcomes of the project include 1) the establishment and refinement of a technical elective in Lehigh's Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, CHE 398/497: Advanced Porous Materials, for advanced undergraduates and graduate students, 2) the development of an educational outreach module delivered and refined as part of Lehigh's Summer Engineering Institute (SEI; previously Pennsylvania Governor's School for Engineering and Technology) impacting high school juniors from across the state of Pennsylvania  (ca. 100 per year), and 3) the enhancement of educational outreach through Lehigh's CHOICES (Charting Horizons and Opportunities in Careers in Engineering and Science) program that engages approximately 60 junior high school aged young women per year in engineering education (ca. 300 students impacted over the course of this project). The junior high and high school initiatives both impacted students from socio-economically diverse schools with otherwise underrepresented groups in engineering and science. In addition to technical publications resulting from this project, one educational publication was also published in Chemical Engineering Education on the SEI outreach initiatives.
